## Understand your responsibilities and keep a record

### Take pictures and keep a record

It may help to take pictures of the problem, especially if it changes. Keep copies of all letters, text messages or emails. 

If you talk to your landlord or the local council on the phone, note the date and time of the call and what you spoke about. If you speak to someone at the council, make a note of their name.

### Problem with electricity or electric wiring ###

Your landlord is responsible for making sure you are not exposed to shocks or burns caused by a faulty electricity supply. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9).

### Problem with gas ###

Your landlord is responsible for making sure the gas supply is safe with no risk of gas leaks. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9).

### Problems with temperature extremes ###

Your landlord is responsible for making sure that living conditions are not too hot or too cold. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9). 

#### Home Heat Helpine ####

Call the home heat helpine if you are worried about paying energy bills and keeping warm in winter. 

Tel: 0800 33 66 99
9am- 5.30pm Monday to Friday 
[www.homeheathelpine.org.uk](www.homeheathelpine.org.uk)

### Problem with hot water supply ###

It is your landlord's responsibility to ensure a reliable supply of hot water, that is free of contaminants. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9).

### Problem with locks on doors ###

It is your landlord's responsibility to make sure that your home can be kept secure. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9).

### Problem with structure of the building, foundations or roof ###

It is your landlord's responsibility to make sure that your home is structurally sound. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9).

### Problem with broken windows or doors ###

It is your landlord's responsibility to make sure that your home can be kept secure. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9).

### Problem with doors or windows that won't open or close ###

It is your landlord's responsibility to make sure that your home can be kept secure. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9).

### Problem with stairs, bannisters or other shared common areas that need repair ###

It is your landlord's responsibility to make sure that falls on stairs are not likely to happen because of disrepair. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9). 

Repairs or upkeep of common areas may not be the sole responsibility of your landlord.

### Problem with access to the property ###

It is your landlord's responsibility to make sure the property is kept clear of anything that blocks access, particularly if this causes a fire hazard. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9).

### Problem with smoke or carbon monoxide detectors ###

It is your landlord's responsibility to make sure smoke and carbon monoxide detectors work properly. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9).

### Problem with fire hazard ###

It is your landlord's responsibility to address any fire hazards if this is not something you are able to fix. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9).

### Problem with a faulty or missing appliance ###

Your landlord or letting agent is only responsible for the maintenance of appliances that were in the property when you moved in.

### Problem with a toilet not working ###

It is your landlord's responsibility to make sure the property has adequate sanitation and drainage. This is covered by the [Housing Act 2004](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hhsrs-operating-guidance-housing-act-2004-guidance-about-inspections-and-assessment-of-hazards-given-under-section-9).

For more details about what you and your landlord are responsible for, see: [https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/housing/renting-privately/during-your-tenancy/dealing-with-repairs/](https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/housing/renting-privately/during-your-tenancy/dealing-with-repairs/).

### Problem with damp or mould ###

It's not always easy to know whether your landlord is responsible for resolving problems with damp. This is because it can be difficult to find the exact cause of damp without the help of a surveyor. 

See this guide about different kinds of damp: 
[https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/housing/repairs-in-rented-housing/repairs-common-problems/repairs-damp/](https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/housing/repairs-in-rented-housing/repairs-common-problems/repairs-damp/)

### Problem with inadequate ventilation ###

You should make sure you are not contributing to the problem of inadequate ventilation. For example by drying clothes on radiators without opening windows, or not using the extractor fan after a shower.

### Problem with damp affecting your health ###

As the damp problem is affecting your health, it may help to get a letter to explain this. Speak to your doctor or other healthcare professional.

### Problem with a leak (inside or outside) ###

It's not always easy to determine whether your landlord is responsible for resolving problems with leaks. 

See this guide for information about when your landlord may have fix leaks or repair water damage: 
[https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/housing/repairs-in-rented-housing/repairs-common-problems/repairs-leak-from-a-neighbouring-property/](https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/housing/repairs-in-rented-housing/repairs-common-problems/repairs-leak-from-a-neighbouring-property/).

### Problem with an infestation ###

It's not always easy to determine whether your landlord is responsible for resolving problems with mice and other infestations. 

See this guide for more information: [https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/housing/repairs-in-rented-housing/repairs-common-problems/repairs-infestations-of-pests-and-vermin/](https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/housing/repairs-in-rented-housing/repairs-common-problems/repairs-infestations-of-pests-and-vermin/).

### Problem with your health ###

Contact your local council if you're not able to continue living in your home because it's making you unwell. They may be able to help arrange emergency housing.  Make sure you keep sick notes and hospital reports. 

#### Claim compensation for damage to your health

You can claim if your physical or mental health is affected by the conditions in your home.

The amount depends on how you were affected and for how long.

You can also claim for:

- loss of earnings if you were unable to work
- extra expenses such as prescriptions or travel to hospital

See the Shelter website for more information: [https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/housing_disrepair_check_if_you_can_claim_compensation](https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/housing_disrepair_check_if_you_can_claim_compensation)
## Work with your landlord or letting agent ##

### You need to tell your landlord or letting agent about the problem ###

Remember to include these things in your letter or email:

- specific details of what you are experiencing 
- date when the problem started 
- anything you have done since the problems started 
- when your landlord can come in to the property

You can use this [letter template](#). Send your letter by post or email. It may be helpful to include pictures of the problem. 

Make sure you keep a record of this letter and the date that you sent it as you may need it in the future. 

#### A guide to working with your landlord ####
[https://www.advicenow.org.uk/know-hows/how-negotiate-your-landlord](https://www.advicenow.org.uk/know-hows/how-negotiate-your-landlord)

### Contact your landlord or letting agent in writing ###

Even if you have already told your landlord about the problem over the phone, by text message or in person, you need to tell them again in writing. This can be by email or letter. 

Remember to include these things in your letter or email:

- specific details of what you are experiencing 
- date when the problem started 
- anything you have done since the problems started 
- when your landlord can come in to the property

You can use this [letter template](#). Send your letter by post or email. It may be helpful to include pictures of the problem. 

Make sure you keep a record of this letter and the date that you sent it as you may need it in the future. 

#### Allow time for your landlord to get back to you ####

Your landlord should get back to you within a reasonable amount of time. This can be anything from XX days for an emergency, to XX weeks for something less serious. 

If you haven't heard back from your landlord, you should try and contact them again. Remember to keep copies of any messages you send, along with the dates you sent them.


#### A guide to working with your landlord ####
[https://www.advicenow.org.uk/know-hows/how-negotiate-your-landlord](https://www.advicenow.org.uk/know-hows/how-negotiate-your-landlord)

### Write to your landlord or letting agent again ###

If you have waited a reasonable amount of time (usually this is XX days), you should write to your landlord again to tell them you will contact your local council for help with fixing the problem.

You an use this [letter template](#). 

Include: 

- details of the problem
- how the problem is affecting you 
- when and how you have already told the landlord about the problem 

It may be helpful to include pictures of the problem. Make sure you keep a record of this letter and the date that you sent it as you may need it in the future. 

#### A guide to working with your landlord ####

[https://www.advicenow.org.uk/know-hows/how-negotiate-your-landlord](https://www.advicenow.org.uk/know-hows/how-negotiate-your-landlord)
## Problem with your landlord or letting agent ##

### Your landlord should not evict you because you asked for repairs to be done ### 

Your landlord has to keep your home in a good condition and do repairs if you need them. They can’t make you leave your home just for asking for repairs to be done - your landlord has to follow a proper eviction process if they want you to leave. 

See more about this on the Citizen's Advice website: 
[https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/housing/renting-privately/ending-your-tenancy/if-youre-being-evicted-because-you-asked-for-repairs](https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/housing/renting-privately/ending-your-tenancy/if-youre-being-evicted-because-you-asked-for-repairs).

### Your landlord may not enter your home without notice ###

It is against the law for landlords to enter your home without giving you notice. It is also against the law for them to arrange for anyone else to enter your home, eg builders, without giving you notice. 

See: [https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/repairs_and_inspections_access_to_your_rented_home](https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/repairs_and_inspections_access_to_your_rented_home).

### Consider making a complaint about a landlord or letting agent ###

If you're unhappy with the way your landlord or letting agent has responded, you could consider making a complaint. For more information, see:  [https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/private_renting/complaints_about_letting_agents](https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/private_renting/complaints_about_letting_agents).
## Local Council ##

### Contact your local council ###

You should contact the housing team at your local council. They have an obligation to make sure that tenants are living in properties that are looked after by landlords, and kept in a reasonable state of repair.

You can find your local council using this service: [https://www.gov.uk/find-local-council](https://www.gov.uk/find-local-council).

Depending on how serious the problem is, the local council may: 

- contact you for more information 
- make an appointment to come and inspect your home 
- arrange for an 'environmental health' team to come and inspect your home 

You can use this [letter template](#). Remember to include:

- details of the problem
- how the problem is affecting you 
- when and how you have already told the landlord about the problem 

It may be helpful to include pictures of the problem. Make sure you keep a record of this letter and the date that you sent it as you may need it in the future.

### Contact your local council again ###

If you have contacted your local council and they have not responded or carried out an informal inspection, you should contact them again and ask for a formal inspection against the Housing Health and Safety Rating System (HHSRS) for rented homes. 

You can use this [letter template](#). 

Remember to include: 

- details of the problem and how it is affecting you
- dates of when you contacted your landlord 
- date when you previously contacted the local council 

#### Consider making a complaint to the local council ####

You can complain if you don't think the council has dealt with your problem properly. 

Ask for a copy of their: 
- housing enforcement policy 
- complaints procedure 

Check the council have followed their own housing enforcement policy. If not, you can use the complaints procedure. You can use this service to complain about your local council: [https://www.gov.uk/complain-about-your-council](https://www.gov.uk/complain-about-your-council).

#### Consider legal action ####

You can take court action to get work done or claim compensation if your landlord fails to deal with repairs, poor conditions or safety issues. 
 
The court can order your landlord to: 
- carry out the repairs 
- pay you compensation 
- make an unsafe property fit to live in 

For more infomattion, see: 
[https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/legal_action_if_your_landlord_wont_do_repairs](https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/legal_action_if_your_landlord_wont_do_repairs)

#### Make a complaint to the Local Government and Social Care Ombudsman ####

If you're not satisfied with the council's response to your complaint, you can complain to the Local Government & Social Care Ombudsman. See: [https://www.lgo.org.uk/](https://www.lgo.org.uk/)

## About mediation and legal action ##

### Apply to the court for an emergency injunction ###

Asking the court to order that repairs be done immediately can only done when the problem is extremely serious. 

You may want to get professional legal advice before starting an application. 

Find out more about applying for an emergency injunction here: [https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/eviction/how_to_get_an_illegal_eviction_injunction](https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/eviction/how_to_get_an_illegal_eviction_injunction)

See more about [finding a lawyer or legal advice](#).

### Consider working with a mediator to resolve the problem ###

A mediator should work with both you and your landlord so that you can find a solution everyone agrees with. 

Mediation is usually less costly than taking legal action. And if you do end up taking legal action, you may be asked for evidence that you tried to mediation first. 

See: [http://www.civilmediation.org](http://www.civilmediation.org)

### About taking legal action ###

#### Taking legal action against your landlord or letting agent ####

Going to court can be expensive and time-consuming, but it is an option if you have not been able to resolve the problem in another way. You may want to talk to a solicitor or qualified legal professional before you start any legal action. 

There is a process you need to follow to make a claim. See the law that protects tenants' living conditions:[https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/homes-fitness-for-human-habitation-act-2018/guide-for-tenants-homes-fitness-for-human-habitation-act-2018](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/homes-fitness-for-human-habitation-act-2018/guide-for-tenants-homes-fitness-for-human-habitation-act-2018)

Going to court can be expensive and time-consuming, but it is an option if you have not been able to resolve the problem in another way. You may want to talk to a solicitor or qualified legal professional before you start any legal action. 

There is a process you need to follow to make a claim. See the law that protects tenants' living conditions: [https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/homes-fitness-for-human-habitation-act-2018/guide-for-tenants-homes-fitness-for-human-habitation-act-2018](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/homes-fitness-for-human-habitation-act-2018/guide-for-tenants-homes-fitness-for-human-habitation-act-2018).

Read more about taking legal action on the [Shelter website](https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/legal_action_if_your_landlord_wont_do_repairs) and the [Citizens Advice website](https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/housing/renting-privately/during-your-tenancy/going-to-court-if-your-landlord-wont-do-repairs/).

### Getting ready for going to court ###

#### Gathering information in preparation for court ####

Before going to court, it is important to gather together enough information to prove the case. This is likely to include:

- proof of when the landlord was told about the problem and copies of any letters and emails
- photographs of the problem 
- any evidence available from experts (eg surveyors, environmental health officers)
- the tenancy agreement and other documents relating to the tenancy
- any relevant medical reports detailing the effects of the bad housing conditions on the health or stress levels of the occupants
- details of any costs incurred as a result of the disrepair.

#### Getting an expert opinion ####

You may need to ask an expert to carry out an inspection and put together a report for the court. Particularly if the problem is complex, or you and your landlord don't agree. 

You may be able to share the cost of an expert opinion with your landlord, or claim the costs back if you win the case. 

For more information about getting a report from an expert, see 

- [The Chartered Institute of Environmental Health, Consultants Directory](http://www.ehn-online.com/consultantsdirectory/consultants.aspx?cdid=5548)
- [The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors’ Find a Surveyor](https://www.ricsfirms.com/)
- [The Expert Witness Directory (2015)](https://www.sweetandmaxwell.co.uk/our-businesses/directories.aspx)

You can also see the Shelter website for more about gathering information in preparation for a court case: [https://england.shelter.org.uk/legal/housing_conditions/taking_action_on_disrepair/county_court_action/gathering_information](https://england.shelter.org.uk/legal/housing_conditions/taking_action_on_disrepair/county_court_action/gathering_information).
